Title: Immediate vs. Early Urinary Catheter Removal after Radical Gastrectomy: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Background: This randomised controlled trial assessed the feasibility of immediate removal (IR) versus early removal (ER) of urinary catheters following radical gastrectomy under enhanced recovery after surgery (ERAS) protocols.

Methods: Conducted at the Affiliated Hospital of Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine, adult patients undergoing radical gastrectomy were randomised 1:1 to IR or ER groups. The primary outcome was postoperative urinary retention (POUR) with a non-inferiority margin of 10%. Secondary outcomes included patient comfort, anxiety, and depression. Randomisation was computer-generated, and neither investigators nor patients were blinded. The trial was registered under NCT06718114.

Participants: Eligibility criteria included adult patients scheduled for elective laparoscopic radical gastrectomy. Exclusions were based on urogenital history or medication affecting urination. Recruitment occurred from December 2021 to June 2024.

Intervention: In the IR group, catheters were removed immediately post-surgery, while in the ER group, removal occurred within 24 hours. Both groups followed ERAS protocols.

Results: Of 248 patients assessed, 92 in the IR group and 89 in the ER group were analysed using intention-to-treat analysis. POUR incidence was 4.4% in the IR group and 3.4% in the ER group (P = 0.733; 1.0% difference, 95% CI âˆ’4.6 to 6.6%). Patient comfort was higher in the IR group (mean Kolcaba General Comfort Questionnaire score 74.9 vs. 72.5; P = 0.041). No severe adverse events were reported.

Interpretation: Immediate catheter removal is non-inferior to early removal in terms of POUR incidence and enhances patient comfort. Successful implementation likely depends on multimodal analgesia and goal-directed fluid therapy.

Funding: The study was funded by the Affiliated Hospital of Nanjing University of Chinese Medicine.
